title.value: A Reduction from Reinforcement Learning to No-Regret Online Learning
title.justification: It is the title provided by the source document.
title.quote: A Reduction from Reinforcement Learning to No-Regret Online Learning

extractions.description: The paper presents a reduction methodology from reinforcement learning (RL) to no-regret online learning using the saddle-point formulation of RL. This approach decomposes the RL problem into two parts: regret minimization and function approximation. By applying this reduction, new RL algorithms can be systematically designed. The paper also proposes an RL algorithm based on mirror descent via a generative-model oracle, providing provable performance guarantees.

type.justification: The paper proposes a new algorithm for RL and demonstrates its performance through empirical evaluation.
type.quote: We demonstrate this idea by devising a simple RL algorithm based on mirror descent and the generative-model oracle.

name.justification: The paper's focus is on devising algorithms for reinforcement learning, which is a subfield of deep learning.
name.quote: Reinforcement Learning (RL) is a fundamental problem for sequential decision making in unknown environments.

name.justification: The main theme of the paper is to reduce reinforcement learning problems to no-regret online learning and to design new RL algorithms.
name.quote: We present a reduction from reinforcement learning (RL) to no-regret online learning based on the saddle-point formulation of RL.

name.justification: The paper proposes and evaluates a simple RL algorithm based on mirror descent.
name.quote: As a demonstration, we design an RL algorithm based on arguably the simplest online learning algorithm: mirror descent.

name.justification: The paper demonstrates the effectiveness of its proposed algorithm using tabular MDPs.
name.quote: We prove that, for any tabular Markov decision process (MDP), with probability at least 1 − δ, this algorithm learns an ǫ-optimal policy

name.justification: The generative-model oracle is used in the paper for implementing the proposed RL algorithm.
name.quote: Assuming a generative model, we prove that, for any tabular Markov decision process
